text:
Alberto Gonzalez says the Follins (who composed Silver Surfer) were one of his biggest inspirations.

This guy composed the Game Boy versions of Turok 1 and Turok 2 - definitely worth a listen if you like this.
author: Chad Serrant

text: Thank you

text: I also thought that at first! But the Silver Surfer soundtrack was done by Tim / Geoff Follin. Check out the Wolverine (NES) music, it's from one of them & equally awesome :)

author: James Rickenberg

text:
There are still MANY great NES composers, though.
Koji Kondo (Super Mario, Zelda) and Nobuo Oematso (Final Fantasy), Manami Matsumae (Mega Man) are just three in my list that i know by name.
But there are plenty of NES games and among them many great memorable tracks (Castlevania, Ducktales ("The Moon"), Contra, etc)
author: LinkEX

text: Limited in terms of sound quality, not for the musical structure (at least not in the SNES).
author: iuri Lua

text: This game is a bare bones platformer. There is literarly one thing you can do. Jump. And the levels are all linear with a boss (a common enemy with more health). And a couple of scrolling levels and waterlevels to spruce it up. Utterly forgetable. But perfect for introducing people to games who have never played one, since its limited they dont get confused ;) Some of my non gamer friends love it. Especially the girls.
author: Ghelma

text: Alberto Gonzalez, heck yeah.
author: Streak

text:
but I still wouldn't say it's fair to compare NES composers with SNES composers because, compared to the NES, you could do MUCH more with the SPC700 than you could ever hope to do with the 2A03, even with expansion chips

so if you narrow it down to NES composers then I'd say gonzalez is definitely in the top 5, if not the top 3
author: DukeOnkledNukem

text: If you think about it, technically real instruments are the ones with limits. Try playing the beginning few seconds of any Pokemon battle theme on Piano and you will see that it is extremely difficult. Or, try playing any Donkey Kong boss theme on piano. Ive seen synthesized versions of damn near impossible songs made, but almost none live. Example: theres a video with the Pokemon GSC Trainer battle played on synthed piano but no live tracks on youtube.
author: Daniel Egan

text: I'm very reluctant to call the snes a limited console in terms of its audio capabilities. It was powerful enough to produce the DKC trilogy, FF4-6 (especially 6), the "diving" track from Waterworld, Chrono Trigger, and others. IMO the biggest generational jump in audio capabilities was the jump from nes to snes (Master System to Genesis......not so much).
